sentences.sentence: Abdulla Shahid President of the UN General Assembly Violence against women was pervasive even before the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, affecting 1 in 3 women and girls worldwide.
Yet the virus's emergence has compounded the underlying realities of sexism and gender-based violence.
Since its spread, 1 in every 2 women report that they, or a woman they know, have experienced some form of violence and abuse.
This silent and hidden “shadow pandemic” reached alarming heights as the isolation and social distancing measures, enacted to contain viral spread, placed many victims in lockdown with their abusers.
Very often those abusers were their own partners or spouses.
When we speak of COVID-19's exacerbation of gender-based violence, we must realize that the underlying issue is not the virus itself, but the fundamental imbalance of power in our societies.
This imbalance is rooted in the belief that violence towards women and girls is normal or appropriate behavior, and is condoned by society.
Violence against women and girls takes many forms.
This includes sexual assault, domestic violence, female genital mutilation, so called “honour” crimes, and forced marriage.
As we speak, an additional 13 million girls are at risk of forced marriage.

Violence against women and girls is not only a human rights violation which upends the security and safety of its victims, but it also impedes women and girls' chances of being full and equal participants in society.
The trauma and scars of abuse can endure for the entirety of their lives.
Children in violent households are 3 to 9 times more likely to be injured and abused.
Violence and the threat of violence can stop girls from going to school, from being able to choose if and who they marry, and from reaching their full potential.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: Remarks by H.E. Abdulla Shahid President of the UN General Assembly Violence against women was pervasive even before the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, affecting 1 in 3 women and girls worldwide. Yet the virus’s emergence has compounded the underlying realities of sexism and gender-based violence. Since its spread, 1 in every 2 women report that they, or a woman they know, have experienced some form of violence and abuse. This silent and hidden “shadow pandemic” reached alarming heights as the isolation and social distancing measures, enacted to contain viral spread, placed many victims in lockdown with their abusers. Very often those abusers were their own partners or spouses. When we speak of COVID-19’s exacerbation of gender-based violence, we must realize that the underlying issue is not the virus itself, but the fundamental imbalance of power in our societies. This imbalance is rooted in the belief that violence towards women and girls is normal or appropriate behavior, and is condoned by society. Violence against women and girls takes many forms. This includes sexual assault, domestic violence, female genital mutilation, so called “honour” crimes, and forced marriage. This violence is ongoing. As we speak, an additional 13 million girls are at risk of forced marriage. Violence against women and girls is not only a human rights violation which upends the security and safety of its victims, but it also impedes women and girls’ chances of being full and equal participants in society. The trauma and scars of abuse can endure for the entirety of their lives. Children in violent households are 3 to 9 times more likely to be injured and abused. Violence and the threat of violence can stop girls from going to school, from being able to choose if and who they marry, and from reaching their full potential.
